message: I’m excited to kick off the new session of Congress today and get to work as Chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee. We will address the real issues holding back job growth and wage growth in America, reform the way our health care is delivered, and take on excessive and unnecessary rules and regulations. This is a new chapter in American history, and I look forward to a lot of work getting done this year for Oregonians and all Americans.

I’m proud to report that the Midnight Rules Relief Act passed the House today. All too often, we see last-minute, burdensome and unnecessary regulations implemented in the final days of a presidential administration on their way out the door. This legislation will block these “midnight rules”, and help protect hardworking Oregonians from even more onerous regulations that haven’t been properly vetted.

GOOD NEWS: Just one week into the new session of Congress, we took swift action in the House to rein in costly, burdensome, and overreaching federal regulations. On Wednesday, we passed legislation to make sure departing presidents of either party can’t hand down unnecessary, midnight rules on their way out the door. And yesterday, we passed the REINS Act that requires major regulations be approved by Congress, not just implemented by unelected bureaucrats in D.C. These plans will rein in out of control regulators like the EPA, and help grow the economy and protect small businesses in Oregon.

Good news: the House unanimously passed legislation I introduced to reduce government red tape holding back small businesses across the country. The Small Business Broadband Deployment Act lifts unnecessary regulatory burdens on small internet service providers – who so often serve customers in rural areas like Eastern Oregon. This bill allows these small businesses to focus on the core mission of serving their customers, not complying with onerous reporting requirements. Read more about this legislation here: https://energycommerce.house.gov/news-center/press-releases/house-advances-two-energy-and-commerce-committee-bills

With this designation, the outgoing administration is locking up more of our public lands through a process that cut out many in the surrounding communities. It appears like it was rigged from the beginning. I’ve heard from landowners and county commissioners who were not even consulted in the crafting of the proposal. The Clinton Administration similarly rushed to declare the original Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument at the last minute without the necessary work upfront. As a result, I had to come back and legislate a solution around Soda Mountain. It is unfortunate that the current administration has followed the same failed pattern. I will work with the Trump Administration to do what we can to roll back this midnight expansion.

It was great to welcome my friend Jake Hurley and his dad, Peter, back to the nation’s capital today. Jake nearly lost his life during the 2008 outbreak of salmonella in products produced by the Peanut Corporation of America. Jake’s story, along with countless others affected by the outbreak, helped bring justice to bad actors at the Peanut Corporation of America who were responsible for the outbreak. After the outbreak, the Energy and Commerce Committee launched an investigation to make sure Peanut Corporation of America – and its leaders like Stewart Parnell – were held accountable for knowingly endangering Oregonians like Jake and Americans across the country. Due in part to Jake’s testimony, Stewart Parnell received a 28-year prison sentence for his role in the outbreak – the toughest penalty for a corporate executive in a food poisoning case. It was good to see you again, Jake, and I’m glad to see that you’re doing well.

Enough smoke. Enough fires.  Enough is enough. When Cycle Oregon and performances at the Shakespeare Festival in Ashland get canceled because of fires and the toxic smoke, it’s long past time for Congress to address how federal forests are managed and how fires are fought (or not), including policies that affect firefighting in wilderness areas.   When people in Central Oregon, the Gorge (or just about anywhere on the east side this summer) are told to stay inside, it’s time for a change in federal policy so that decisions to let fires burn include a review of how doing so will add carbon and toxic pollutants into the atmosphere, threaten habitat and water quality and destroy private timberlands and property.  It’s also time for the U.S. Senate to stop blocking our bipartisan legislation that has passed overwhelmingly in the House year-after-year which would help prevent catastrophic forest fires by allowing proper management. Further, the bill would provide resources to clean up after forest fires and restore the forests with new trees for another generation.   The House Resources Committee has once again approved legislation-- the Resilient Federal Forests Act--that solves the fire borrowing problem, but more importantly, gives foresters and firefighters new tools to help protect our forests, watersheds and airsheds from the kinds of disasters we endured this summer. I know we’re always going to have fires, but we must find better ways to control and extinguish them.   Soon the House will take up this measure and send it to the Senate. I’m convinced President Trump will sign it into law if only we can get it to his desk.

Per USFS: Chetco Bar Fire https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5385/#  The Chetco Bar Fire was reported on July 12, 2017. The initial size-up of the fire was 1/4 acre burning in the 2002 Biscuit Fire and 1987 Silver Fire scars located in the Kalmiopsis Wilderness, roughly six air miles west of Pearsoll Peak and north of the Chetco River. Any private aircraft or drone that violates the TFR could face serious criminal charges. Even without a TFR, anyone who hampers firefighting efforts could face criminal charges as well. For more information on drone use, visit the FAA's website www.KnowBeforeYouFly.org. Remember, "If you fly, we can't!" Per USFS: High Cascades Complex Fire https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5503/#  Fire Location: The High Cascades Complex consists of 20 fires located within Crater Lake National Park, the Rogue River/Siskiyou National Forest on the High Cascades Ranger District, the Umpqua National Forest, Tiller Ranger District, and the Fremont/Winema National Forest in the Sky Lakes wilderness. Thirteen of these fires have been contained and are in patrol status. The remaining 7 are being managed with a full suppression strategy.   Area, Road, and Trail Closures:   Closure orders have been issued by the Umpqua, Rogue River-Siskiyou, and Fremont Winema National Forests due to hazards associated with fire activity. Road, trail, and area closures have been expanded in and around the Abbott Creek Research Natural Area and the northern portion of the Sky Lakes Wilderness, including a portion of the Pacific Crest Trail. For maps and details see: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/closures/5503/  Fire History:  On July 26, 2017, lightning started the Blanket Creek fire within the Blanket Creek drainage on the Rogue River/Siskiyou National Forest. On July 29, 2017, a lightning strike started the Spruce Lake fire, burning on the west side of Crater Lake National Park. Continuing lightning events over the following week initiated numerous starts across the region. Northwest Incident Management Team (NWIMT) 7 (Knerr) began management of the High Cascades Complex on August 24, 2017. Transfer of management of the Paradise, Windy Gap and Pup fires in the Falcon Complex from NWIMT 8 (Keith) to NWIMT 7 (Knerr), occurred on Saturday, August 26, 2017. The Pup, Paradise, and Windy Gap Fires are now listed under the High Cascades Complex.   NWIMT 7 is now managing a total of 20 fires in Crater Lake National Park, Rogue River-Siskiyou, Fremont-Winema, and Umpqua National Forests. Like all Americans, I will never forget where I was on the morning of September 11, 2001 when our country was attacked.  Still reeling from the attack on the World Trade Center in New York City, Members of Congress were told to evacuate the Capitol immediately after another plane tore through the Pentagon. It was believed the Capitol building was also a target and if it were not for the bravery of 40 Americans aboard United Airlines Flight 93 another iconic U.S. symbol and countless more lives would have been lost. The horrifying images from that day are seared into our national conscious and will forever remind us that we are not invincible and that we are stronger together and united. Today, we remember the thousands of lives who were lost. We remember the first responders and everyday citizens who put their lives on the line to save others. As we pause to reflect on this day, let us honor the brave men and women in uniform defending our freedom and way of life each and every day, and let us never forget.

Throwback Thursday: The Steens Mountain Cooperative Management and Protection Act – legislation I introduced – was signed into law by President Clinton in 2000. This legislation established the first of its kind cooperative management program between the BLM, private landowners, ranchers, and local community members around Steens Mountain to protect this treasure of southeast Oregon. Rather than lock up this land with a unilateral monument designation, we created a cooperative spirit between the local community and the federal agencies managing this public land and established the Steens Mountain Cooperative Management and Protection Area which is still successful 17 years later. This is how you work together to protect treasured public lands, and ensure the voice of the local communities on the ground are heard in federal land management decisions.
